metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Role and mechanism of angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 in acute lung injury in coronavirus disease 2019 Review Role and mechanism of angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 in acute lung injury in coronavirus disease 2019 Review Role and mechanism of angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 in acute

abstract.text: Coronavirus disease 2019 is a major threat to public health globally. Though its 6 pathogenesis has not been fully elucidated, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) 7 has been recently identified as a receptor for the entry of severe acute respiratory 8 syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) into the cell. Here, we aimed to clarify the 9 potential role of ACE2 in SARS-CoV-2-induced acute lung injury and its underlying 10

body_text.text: mechanism. As a receptor for coronavirus, ACE2 mediates the entry of SARS-CoV-2 11 into cells in a similar way as for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 12 (SARS-CoV). The high binding affinity of SARS-CoV-2 to ACE2 correlates with its 13 efficient spread among humans. On the other hand, ACE2 negatively regulates the 14 renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) primarily by converting angiotensin II 15 to angiotensin 1-7, which exerts a beneficial effect on coronavirus-induced acute lung 16 injury. Human recombinant ACE2 has been considered as a potential therapy for 17 SARS-CoV-2 by blocking virus entry and redressing the imbalance of RAAS in 18 SARS-CoV-2 infection. The level of ACE2 expression can be upregulated by 19 treatment with an ACE inhibitor (ACEI) or angiotensin type 1 receptor blocker Ⅱ 20 (ARB). To date, no evidence shows that ACEIs or ARBs increase the susceptibility 21 and mortality of patients infected with SARS-CoV-2, and hence, it is not advisable to 22 discontinue such drugs in patients with cardiovascular disease. Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), an important metalloproteinase, plays 51 a key role in SARS-CoV-2 infection. 1 ACE2 not only mediates viral infection but also 52 exerts important regulatory effects on the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system 53 (RAAS) and participates in the development of acute lung injury (ALI) after infection. 54

Intervention measures that target ACE2 may improve the prognosis of patients with 55 COVID-19. This paper comprehensively describes ACE2 structure and function, 56 regulation of ACE2 expression, and its role in viral infection and ALI. 57 58 ACE2 overview 59 ACE2 was discovered in 2000 as a homolog of angiotensin-converting enzyme 60 (ACE). 5,6 ACE2 is a type I transmembrane protein comprised of 805 amino acids. 61 ACE2 contains two domains, the amino-terminal and the carboxy-terminal domain. 62

The amino-terminal catalytic domain contains one active site, a zinc metalloprotein 63 domain that shares 41.8% sequence identity with ACE. 5-7 The gene that encodes 64 ACE2 is located on the X-chromosome at Xp22.2. 8 ACE2 is expressed in the human 65 heart, kidneys, lungs, liver, testes, and intestines. 6 In the heart and large vessels, 66 ACE2 is localized on the surface of endothelial and smooth muscle cells. In the 67 kidneys, ACE2 is mainly expressed on the apical membrane of proximal tubular 68 epithelial cells and colocalized with ACE. 9 In the lungs, ACE2 is mainly located on 69 type II pneumocytes, or may be found on type I pneumocytes and airway epithelial 70 cells. 10 71 72
The functions of ACE2 can be broadly classified into two types: protease and 74 protease-independent functions. 75

ACE2 is a metalloproteinase and its active domain is exposed on the cell surface 77 to facilitate the catalysis of circulating polypeptides. ACE2 can cleave angiotensin I 78 into inactive angiotensin 1-9 (Ang 1-9) peptide, 5,6 which is further converted by ACE 79 or other peptidases into angiotensin 1-7 (Ang 1-7) peptide. 5 Moreover, ACE2 can 80 efficiently metabolize angiotensin (Ang ) into Ang 1 Ⅱ Ⅱ -7, which binds to Mas 81 receptor (Mas), a G-protein coupled receptor, to exert vasodilation and 82
anti-proliferation effects. 11 It is well established that Ang II has two G-protein-coupled receptors, the angiotensin type 1 receptor (AT1R) and 84 angiotensin receptor type 2 receptor (AT2R).

Ⅱ Ang II exerts its biological functions 85 and is involved in in pathogenesis of various diseases mainly through AT1R. The 86 activation of ACE/Ang II/AT1R pathway leads to vasoconstriction, proliferation, 87 fibrosis and inflammation, which may ultimately result in progressive tissue damage. 9 88
The effects of Ang 1-7 counterbalance the deleterious effects of the ACE/Ang 89 II/AT1R pathway 12-15 ( Figure 1 ). Ang 1-7 exerts multiple cardioprotective effects, 90

including anti-inflammatory, anti-thrombotic, anti-fibrotic, anti-arrhythmic, and 91 natriuretic effects. It has also been shown to inhibit cardiac hypertrophy and plaque 92 formation, and ameliorate vascular dysfunction. 16 The ACE2/Ang 1-7/Mas pathway 93 has shown beneficial effects in many animal models of hypertension, heart failure, 94 ischemic cardiomyopathy, and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy. 17 In the lungs, the Ang 95

and pro-inflammatory cytokines to alleviate lung inflammation. In addition, it also 97 improves oxygenation, reduces airway hyperresponsiveness, decreases alveolar 98 epithelial cell apoptosis, and inhibits fibroblast proliferation and migration, goblet cell 99 metaplasia, and airway remodeling. The ACE2/Ang 1-7/Mas pathway has been 100 shown to exert protective effects on the lungs in animal models of ARDS, asthma, 101 pulmonary fibrosis, and pulmonary hypertension. 18 In addition, in vitro experiments 102 have shown that ACE2 cleaves apelin-13 to remove one amino acid from the 103 C-terminal, 11 which affects the hypotensive effects of apelin-13. 104 105 106

body_text.text: In addition to protein cleavage, ACE2 has other important biological functions. 108 with the AT1R antagonists, losartan and olmesartan, for 28 days, the cardiomyocyte 151 ACE2 mRNA level increased by 97% and 42%, respectively. This suggested that the 152 cardioprotective effects of AT1R antagonists on myocardial infarction were partially 153 mediated by ACE2. Subsequent studies showed that myocardial ACE2 mRNA levels 154

were significantly increased when lisinopril, losartan, and a combination of these two 155 drugs were administered to rats continuously for 12 days. In addition, losartan 156 monotherapy or combined therapy with lisinopril has been shown to significantly 157 increase myocardial ACE2 activity in rats. 31 186 The whole genome sequence of SARS-CoV-2 was successfully determined by 187 next-generation sequencing 1 . A comparison with the genome sequences of previously 188 detected coronaviruses showed that SARS-CoV-2 was closely related to two bat 189

Evolutionary analysis showed that SARS-CoV-2 belonged to the subgenus 191 Sarbecovirus in the genus Betacoronavirus. A comparison of the spike protein 192 sequences between SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV showed that the similarity of the 193 entire spike protein sequence was 76%-78%, RBD was 73%-76%, and receptor 194 binding motif (RBM) was 50%-53%. 37 The high sequence similarity in spike proteins 195 between these two viruses suggested that they utilized the same receptor, ACE2. 196 Further analysis showed that ACE2 not only mediated SARS-CoV-2 infection in 197
body_text.section: SARS-like viruses (88% similarity): bat-SL-CoVZC45 and bat-SL-CoVZXC21. 190

body_text.text: humans, but also resulted in human-to-human transmission. The RBD of 198 SARS-CoV-2 interacted with ACE2 through its polar residues. 38 virus-binding hotspots at the RBD/ACE2 interface, which increased binding interface 204 stability. Therefore, the affinity between the RBD of SARS-CoV-2 and ACE2 was 205 significantly higher than that between the RBD of SARS-CoV and ACE2. 42 The 206
body_text.section: SARS-like viruses (88% similarity): bat-SL-CoVZC45 and bat-SL-CoVZXC21. 190

body_text.text: higher affinity of SARS-CoV-2 for ACE2 enabled easier human-to-human 207 transmission. 43 Hoffmann et al 44 performed in vitro experiments and showed that 208 SARS-CoV-2 used host cell proteases to cleave the spike protein at the S1/S2 and S2' 209 sites, thereby activating it, and then utilized ACE2 as a receptor to enter target cells. 210
body_text.section: SARS-like viruses (88% similarity): bat-SL-CoVZC45 and bat-SL-CoVZXC21. 190

body_text.text: Both SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV used transmembrane serine protease 2 to activate 211 their spike proteins. Unlike in SARS-CoV, a furin cleavage site has been shown to be 212 present between the S1/S2 subunits in SARS-CoV-2. 38 infected with SARS-CoV-2. In addition, ALI was shown to be less severe in complete 230

body_text.text: Ace knockout (Ace -/ -) mice, followed by partial Ace knockout (Ace + / -) mice, which 231 suggested that the expression level of ACE was associated with the severity of lung 232 injury. Furthermore, lung injury was found to be less severe in AT1a receptor 233 knockout mice than that in wild-type mice. 49 In another study, the expression level of 234

body_text.text: Ang II in mice was increased after injection of recombinant SARS spike protein, and 235 treatment with an AT1R antagonist alleviated acute respiratory distress in these 236

body_text.text: was associated with ARDS susceptibility and prognosis. The proportion of ARDS 238 patients with the D/D genotype was higher than that of control individuals with the 239 D/D genotype, and the mortality rate of ARDS patients with the D/D genotype was 240 higher than that of ARDS patients with the I/I genotype. 50 These results showed that 241 ACE/Ang /AT1R might mediate ALI pathogenesis.
body_text.section: mice. 25 A cohort study showed that insertion/deletion (I/D) polymorphism in ACE 237

body_text.text: Ⅱ 242 In an animal model of ALI induced by acid aspiration and sepsis, the 249 clinicopathological presentation of Ace2 knockout mice was worse than that of 250 wild-type mice, and the mortality rate was increased. 49 To further validate the effects 251 of ACE2 in ALI, Imai et al 49 injected recombinant human ACE2 (rhACE2) into these 252 mice. The results showed that treatment with rhACE2 significantly alleviated lung 253 injury induced by acid aspiration. This phenomenon was present in both Ace2 254 knockout and wild-type mice. However, injection of rhACE2 without catalytic 255 activity could not alleviate acid aspiration-induced ALI. These results suggest that 256 ACE2 with catalytic activity has a protective role in ALI. 257
body_text.section: mice. 25 A cohort study showed that insertion/deletion (I/D) polymorphism in ACE 237

body_text.text: In an acid aspiration-induced ALI model, the Ang II levels in the lungs and 258 plasma of Ace2 knockout mice were found to be significantly higher than those in 259 wild-type mice. However, treatment with rhACE2 alleviated lung injury and 260 simultaneously decreased Ang II expression, and treatment with an AT1R antagonist 261 or ACE inactivation alleviated ALI in Ace2 knockout mice. 49 These results suggested 262 that ACE2 negatively regulated ACE/Ang I /AT1R to alleviate ALI. Although there is few direct evidence of SARS-CoV-2-induced ALI, we 296 speculate that SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV have a similar pathogenesis owing to 297 their high homology. An in-depth understanding of the pathogenesis of SARS-CoV-2 298 will help in the development of targeted interventions to control the COVID-19 299 epidemic. ACE2 is not only a receptor that mediates coronavirus infection, but is also 300 an important RAAS enzyme that regulates virus infection-induced ALI. Although 301 increased ACE2 expression may elevate the risk of coronavirus infection, it may also 302 have protective effects against ALI. However, the effects of enhanced ACE2 303 expression (such as RAAS inhibition) on SARS-CoV-2 susceptibility and patient 304 outcomes are not fully understood, and further basic and clinical studies are urgently 305 required. 306

FIGREF0.text: until March 22, 2020, coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by 27 severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has resulted in 28 292,142 confirmed infections and 12,784 deaths in 171 countries and regions 29

FIGREF1.text: ACE2 was confirmed to be a receptor for SARS-CoV. 19 ACE2 mediates 109 infection of this virus, which is independent of its protease activity. Structural 110 analysis shows that the spike protein of SARS-CoV comes in contact with the apex of subunit I in the catalytic domain of ACE2 without involvement of subunit II and does 112 not block the active site. Once the receptor binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV 113 spike protein binds to ACE2, the extracellular domain of ACE2 is cleaved and the 114 transmembrane domain migrates into the cell, mediating further fusion between virus 115 particles and host cells 20 (Figure 2). 116 117 ACE2 also participates in amino acid absorption in the intestine. In the intestine, 118 ACE2 binds to the B 0 AT1 amino acid transporter 21 to mediate neutral amino acid 119 absorption. This amino acid transport function is not associated with the protease 120 activity of ACE2. 121 122 Regulation of ACE2 expression 123 Regulation of ACE2 expression by pathophysiological status 124 ACE2 mRNA and protein levels were shown to be downregulated in the kidneys 125 of mouse models of hypertension and diabetes. 8,22 Zisman et al 23 observed that the 126 ACE2 protein level was significantly increased in failing human hearts with 127 idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy. Brake et al. showed elevated ACE2 protein levels 128 in the lung tissues of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and 129 smokers with normal lung function. 24 Kuba et al 25 demonstrated that ACE2 protein 130 expression was significantly decreased in a mouse model of ALI. Koitka et al 26 131 discovered that ACE2 mRNA and protein levels were significantly decreased in rats 132 with kidney disease or rats that underwent subtotal nephrectomy. However, the 133 precise molecular mechanism of ACE2 regulation remains unclear. Some 134 transcriptional and post-transcriptional mechanisms have been investigated. ACE2 135 was recognized as a target gene for hepatocyte nuclear factor 1β (HNF-1β), as binding 136 sites for HNF-1β were identified in the promoter regions of ACE2. 27 Accumulation of 137 hypoxia-inducible factor-1α, a crucial transcription factor, was found to decrease 138 ACE2 mRNA and protein levels at the later stages of hypoxia. 28 Energy stress has 139 been shown to regulate ACE2 mRNA expression by activating adenosine 140 monophosphate kinase, following which sirtuin 1 binds to the promoter region of 141 ACE2 and enhances its transcription. 17 Furthermore, microRNA-421 was shown to 142 bind with the 3ʹ-untranslated region of ACE2 transcript and reduce ACE2 protein 143 level post-transcriptionally. 29 144 Regulation of ACE2 expression by drugs 145 RAAS inhibitors, including ACE inhibitors (ACEIs) and AT1R antagonists, can 146 upregulate ACE2 mRNA levels. Ishiyama et al 30 employed a rat model of myocardial 147infarction to assess the effects of myocardial infarction on myocardial ACE2 mRNA 148 expression. The results showed that myocardial infarction did not cause significant 149 changes in the myocardial ACE2 mRNA level; however, when the rats were treated 150

FIGREF2.text: Keidar et al 32 showed that 158 mineralocorticoid(aldosterone) inhibition could inhibit oxidative stress through the 159 Ang /nuclear factor Ⅱ -κB signaling pathway, thereby increasing macrophage ACE2 160 mRNA levels in patients with heart failure. Interferon-γ and interleukin-4 could 161 reduce ACE2 mRNA levels and ACE2 expression in epithelial cells in vitro to 162 decrease susceptibility to SARS-CoV. 33 Additionally, Tikoo et al 34 showed that ACE2 163 protein but not mRNA expression was downregulated in the rabbit heart and kidneys 164 in a high-cholesterol diet-induced atherosclerosis model. However, atorvastatin 165 treatment increased ACE2 protein expression in the heart and kidneys, but only 166 increased ACE2 mRNA level in the heart. Furthermore, enhanced occupancy of histone H3 acetylation mark on the promoter region of ACE2 was observed in the 168 heart after atorvastatin treatment, suggesting that epigenetic regulation might be 169 involved. 170 171 Other regulatory mechanisms of ACE2-shedding and internalization 172 In 2003, ACE2 was confirmed to be a receptor for SARS-CoV. After the spike 173 protein of SARS-CoV comes in contact with ACE2, the complete molecular structure 174 or transmembrane domain of ACE2 and the virus are endocytosed (internalized) using 175 clathrin. Under the effects of trypsin and furin, the spike proteins are further activated 176 to induce membrane fusion, and the virus RNA is released into the cytoplasm, thereby 177 infecting the cell 19 . In addition, cleavage of the extracellular domain of ACE2 178 (shedding) can occur under the action of the transmembrane protein, a disintegrin and 179 metalloprotease 17 (ADAM17), to release the catalytic domain to the extracellular 180 space 35 . Although the physiological function of shedding has not been fully elucidated, 181 studies have shown that it is associated with virus entry into cells and virus replication 182 36 . In brief, internalization and shedding decrease ACE2 expression on the cell 183 surface. 184 185

This 201 resulted in a tighter conformation in the ridge structure and the Ala475-containing 202 loop approached ACE2. In addition, structural changes were observed in two 203

FIGREF4.text: Bao et al 45 showed that 213 SARS-CoV-2 could infect transgenic mice expressing human ACE2 to cause 214 interstitial pneumonia, and the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 colocalized with ACE2 215 receptors on alveolar epithelial cells. These results show that ACE2 acts as a receptor 216 for SARS-CoV-2 and mediates viral infection of cells. 217

FIGREF5.text: of RAAS in the pathophysiology of ALI 220 ARDS is the most severe form of ALI. Severe lung infection, aspiration, sepsis, 221 and trauma can cause diffuse alveolar damage. Its pathological presentation includes 222 increased capillary permeability, characterized by the presence of neutrophils, macrophages, and protein-rich fluid in the alveolar cavity, and formation of hyaline 224 membranes. 46,47 Since the discovery of SARS-CoV-induced ARDS in 2003, the role 225 of RAAS in ARDS and ALI has attracted widespread attention. In an animal model of 226 ALI induced by acid aspiration, the Ang II levels in the mouse lungs and plasma were 227 significantly increased, and ACE inactivation decreased Ang II levels. The latest study 228 by Liu et al 48 showed that Ang II levels were significantly elevated in patients 229

FIGREF6.text: Mas disequilibrium 244 SARS-CoV infection or injection with recombinant SARS spike protein was 245 shown to significantly decrease the expression of ACE2 in the lungs of mice and in 246 vitro-cultured cells. 25 Reduced ACE2 expression exacerbated ALI induced by various 247 etiologies, such as coronavirus infection.248

FIGREF7.text: Besides type I and II pneumocytes and vascular endothelial cells, SARS-CoV 264can also infect pulmonary epithelial progenitor cells through ACE2, thereby affecting265 lung tissue repair after ALI. 51 266 267 Potential therapeutic value of ACE2 in COVID-19 268 There is currently no specific treatment for COVID-19. As the imbalance between 269 ACE and ACE2 plays an important role in SARS-CoV-2-induced ALI, interventions 270 targeting ACE2 may improve the prognosis of patients with severe COVID-19. In 271 various animal models of ALI, administration of rhACE2 has been shown to improve 272 distribution of pulmonary blood flow, lung function, and elastance, and attenuate 273 edema formation, hypoxemia, and pulmonary hypertension. 49,52 Moreover, rhACE2 274 was found to be capable of binding to the coronavirus directly. Li et al 19 showed that a 275 soluble form of ACE2 could bind the S1 domain of the SARS-CoV spike protein in 276 Vero E6 cells with a high affinity. Hofmann et al 53 proved that the soluble ACE2 277 ectodomain dose-dependently blocked SARS-CoV spike-induced pseudovirus 278 infection of 293T cells. Recent in vitro experiments by Monteil et al. showed that rhACE2 dose-dependently decreased SARS-CoV-2 growth in Vero E6 cells by a 280 factor of 1,000-5,000, and effectively inhibited SARS-CoV-2 infection of human 281 blood vessel and kidney organoids in vitro, which suggested that rhACE2 could block 282 the early entry of SARS-CoV-2 into host cells. 54 In addition, previous studies have 283 validated the safety of rhACE2 in healthy volunteers and patients with ARDS without 284 any adverse effects on hemodynamic parameters. 55-57 Currently, the application of 285 rhACE2 in patients with severe COVID-19 is in the trial phase (Clinicaltrials.gov 286 #NCT04287686). Activators of ACE2, such as diminazene aceturate have been 287 shown to increase the enzymatic activity of ACE2 and might exert protective effects 288 on SARS-CoV-2-induced ALI. 58 Besides, ACEIs and AT1R antagonists can be used 289 to inhibit the effect of the ACE/Ang II/AT1R axis to alleviate lung injury. According 290 to two recent observational studies, there is no evidence as yet that ACEIs or AT1R 291 antagonists enhance the risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection. 59,60 Similarly, Ang 1-7 292peptide may be used for its protective effects on lung tissues through Mas.

TABREF0.text: (https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/situation-reports, 30accessed Mar 22, 2020). COVID-19 is currently a significant threat to global public 31 SARS-CoV-2 is an enveloped, positive-sense single-stranded RNA virus 33 belonging to the genus Betacoronavirus and subgenus Sarbecovirus. Currently, this 34 virus is believed to originate from bats and is transmitted to humans through an 35 intermediate host before human-to-human transmission, which results in the spread of 36 the disease.1 The gene sequence of SARS-CoV-2 shares 79% and 50% similarity with 37 that of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and Middle East 38 respiratory syndrome coronavirus, respectively, and it is highly infectious. 2 Infection 39 with SARS-CoV-2 is characterized by fever, fatigue, and cough, but some patients40 also develop myalgia, dyspnea, and gastrointestinal symptoms, such as diarrhea, 41 nausea, and vomiting. Severe dyspnea and hypoxemia occurs within one week of 42 onset in severely affected patients, which rapidly progresses to acute respiratory 43 distress syndrome (ARDS) (in 41.8% of patients), shock, multi-organ failure, or even 44 death (in 21.9% of patients). 3 Lung autopsies of patients who had severe COVID-19 45 showed alveolar epithelial cell detachment, pulmonary interstitial lymphocyte 46 infiltration, and hyaline membrane formation, which suggested the development of 47 ARDS. Multinucleated syncytial cells and atypical enlarged pneumocytes could be 48 observed in the alveoli, which are indicators of virus-infected cells; however, virus 49 inclusion bodies were not detected. 4 50
